content.description:
Include correctly labeled diagrams, if useful or required, in explaining your answers. A correctly labeled diagram must have all axes and curves clearly labeled and must show directional changes. If the question prompts you to “Calculate,” you must show how you arrived at your final answer.

The graph provided shows the demand <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>D</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, long-run average total cost <math alttext="L R A T C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>LRATC</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, marginal cost <math alttext="M C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>MC</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and marginal revenue <math alttext="M R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>MR</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> curves for a natural monopoly.

(a) Over the output range of 0 to 60 units, is this firm experiencing economies of scale, diseconomies of scale, or constant returns to scale? Explain.

(b) Using numbers from the graph, identify the price and quantity produced at which the monopolist earns zero economic profit.

(c) Assume that regulators impose a price ceiling that results in the firm producing the socially optimal quantity in the short run.

(i) Calculate the total revenue at the price ceiling. Show your work.

(ii) Explain why the firm requires a subsidy to continue producing in the long run.

(iii) Calculate the lump-sum subsidy that would be required for the monopolist to produce the socially optimal quantity in the long run. Show your work.
